Ra) is widely used for the
treatment of bone metastasis in patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer.
Rn) which is a noble-gas isotope, and
Rn may escape from patients treated with
Ra via their respiration. In this study,
Rn contained in the breath of patients treated with
Ra to estimate its effect on the internal exposure dose of caregivers.
A total of 12 breath samples were collected using a breath collection bag
from a total of six patients treated with
breath was collected in a breath bag at 1 min and at 5 min after the start of
administration. The contents of each bag were measured using an HPGe detector,
Rn was quantified based on the detection of the
Bi, which is a descendant nuclide of
Rn, persisting in the breath bag. The
effective dose to caregivers arising from the inhalation of
referring to the scenario for the calculation of release criteria established for
Rn was observed. Using the observed
Rn per unit breath volume at 1 min and 5 min after the start of
administration were calculated as 90 ± 56 Bq/mL and 28 ± 9 Bq/mL, respectively. The
Rn to caregivers was estimated to be 3.5
Rn in the exhaled breath of patients treated with
was quantitatively calculated using breath collection bags. The internal
